name: methyl_propyl_sulfide
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.
Reason: The basic unit for our comparison will be ethane, which has a melting point of -172.0°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of a methyl group, a propyl group, and a sulfur atom. Each of these functional groups will contribute to the melting point in different ways: (1) The methyl group (–CH3) adds approximately +20°C due to increased molecular weight and rigidity; (2) The propyl group (–CH2CH2–) adds roughly +10°C due to increased molecular weight and rigidity; (3) The sulfur atom (S) can add approximately +20°C due to the presence of a sulfur atom, which can participate in hydrogen bonding and increase the melting point.
